description: From Middle English quenchen, from Old English cwenċan, from Proto-Germanic *kwankijaną.

entries.meaning: The act of quenching something; the fact of being quenched.
(physics) The abnormal termination of operation of a superconducting magnet, occurring when part of the superconducting coil enters the normal (resistive) state.
(physics) A rapid change of the parameters of a physical system.

verbs.description: quench (third-person singular simple present quenches, present participle quenching, simple past and past participle quenched)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To satisfy, especially a literal or figurative thirst.
examples: The library quenched her thirst for knowledge.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To extinguish or put out (as a fire or light).
(transitive, metallurgy) To cool rapidly by direct contact with liquid coolant, as a blacksmith quenching hot iron.
examples: The swordsmith quenched the sword in an oil bath so that it wouldn't shatter.

entries.meaning: (transitive, chemistry) To terminate or greatly diminish (a chemical reaction) by destroying or deforming the remaining reagents.
(transitive, physics) To rapidly change the parameters of a physical system.
(transitive, physics) To rapidly terminate the operation of a superconducting electromagnet by causing part or all of the magnet's windings to enter the normal, resistive state.
examples: If someone is pinned against the MRI magnet by a ferromagnetic object, you may need to quench the magnet in order to free them.
